children.text: On Tuesday,
The Hill
published an
opinion piece

by former Connecticut Sen. Joe Lieberman in which the Democrat-turned-independent gushed over Sen. Joe Manchin’s “sensible suggestion” to stall debate on Democrats’ reconciliation package. It’s no surprise that Lieberman likes Manchin: Not only has the West Virginia Senator taken up Lieberman’s  old corporate Democratic villain role, but Manchin’s attempts to sabotage his own party’s social agenda play right into the hands of Lieberman’s Wall Street masters.
Also, Sen. Kyrsten Sinema is refusing to consider higher taxes on the wealthy corporations — after voting no on the Trump tax cuts and campaigning against them.
Find out about such corporate hackery and much more in today’s Midday Poster below, exclusive for subscribers.
TODAY’S QUOTE:

“This was a crusade without precedent in America, and it was something short of a miracle that this professor-Senator, a devotee of poetry and philosophy, could become a serious contender for the Presidency. It proved that a large segment of the American population is ready and eager for Humanization… indicating that hope and the will for change are alive.” — Philosopher and psychologist Erich Fromm on 1968 presidential candidate Sen. Eugene McCarthy in his book,
The Revolution of Hope: Toward A Humanized Technology
TODAY’S READS:
The John Deere Strike Shows The Tight Labor Market Is Ready To Pop
Why Colin Powell's Iraq Speech At The U.N. Was So Crucial (And Bad)
Amazon Copied Products And Rigged Search Results To Promote Its Brands
Nonprofit Fundraising Off Breast Cancer Has Ties To Scam PAC Networks
Ida’s Forgotten Victims

children.html: Tip Jar

children.text: TODAY’S STAT:

Sen. Joe Manchin, D-W.Va., is reportedly demanding that Democrats impose a $60,000 family income cap on their child tax credit and “a firm work requirement,” as part of their health care, climate, and anti-poverty reconciliation package, according to
Axios
New experimental data from the
U.S. Census Bureau

reveals the devastating impact of such restrictions. According to the data, nearly three quarters of households that reported receiving a child tax credit payment in the past month say that they are either mostly spending it or using it to pay off debt, rather than mostly saving it.

Moreover, two thirds of households earning between $75,000 and $100,000 report mostly spending their child tax credit or using it to pay off debt. Even a slim majority of families earning between $150,000 and $200,000 say they are putting their child tax credit to use, not saving it.
TODAY’S SCOOP:
“Beware the tea party of the left,” former Connecticut Sen. Joe Lieberman wrote in an
opinion piece
Tuesday in
The Hill
praising conservative Manchin for stalling Democrats’ $3.5 trillion economic, health care, and climate reconciliation package.
We all of course remember Lieberman, a Democrat-turned-Independent, from his role as the rotating corporate villain in the Democratic caucus during President Barack Obama’s first term. Lieberman
helped crush efforts
to include a public option in Democrats’ 2010 Affordable Care Act, and also killed a compromise plan to allow people to buy into Medicare at age to 55 — despite having
publicly supported the latter idea
three months earlier.
Now, Lieberman has come to pay his respects to one of the Democratic Party’s current primary corporate villains, Manchin.

children.html: Give a Gift Subscription

children.text: “When Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) made the sensible suggestion to put a ‘strategic pause’ on the reconciliation debate to give Congress the proper time to review and discuss these proposals that touch almost every facet of American life — from child care and education to health care and energy and climate change — he was unfairly shouted down as a traitor to the Democratic party,” Lieberman wrote.

He continued: “Rather than accepting the limits of their political power, the tea party of the left is working to leverage it into more than it really is. Rather than seeking common ground with more moderate Democrats and Republicans, they use over-the-top rhetoric to demonize them, and presume that any difference of opinion is born of corruption or greed.”

Speaking of corruption: Lieberman works for a lobbying firm, Kasowitz Benson Torres LLP, a fact that was not disclosed in the piece. While he generally avoids registering to lobby, Lieberman’s firm bio suggests he represents clients that could have an interest in shredding Democrats’ reconciliation bill. According to
Kasowitz’s website
, Lieberman “assists corporate clients on homeland and national security, defense, health, energy, environmental policy, and intellectual property matters.”
The Hill
column does note that Lieberman is the “the founding chairman of No Labels.” It does not mention that No Labels is a dark money organization
actively working
to block
Democrats’ reconciliation bill, and a pro-business front group that
looks to raise money
from Wall Street and billionaire GOP donors.
In June,
The Intercept
reported that Manchin had just held a Zoom call with No Labels, billionaire investors, and Lieberman, where Manchin named some items he wanted to cut from the reconciliation bill.
Lieberman praised Manchin in another interview earlier this week with the
Hartford Courant
, telling the paper, “I admire what he’s doing.”

“As another great Democratic leader might say, I feel Joe Manchin’s pain,” he said. “He’s been really targeted by people in the Democratic Party, but he is fighting for the type of government that he has fought for most of his life. So they’ve got to accommodate him. That’s the nature of the process.”
TODAY’S FLASHBACK:

Sen. Kyrsten Sinema, D-Ariz., is attempting to single-handedly block Democrats from paring back Donald Trump’s tax cuts for the wealthy and corporations to fund the social and climate measures in their reconciliation bill — even though she voted against those Trump tax cuts in the House and then even campaigned against them during her Senate bid.
Politico
reported

Wednesday that “Sinema remains opposed to one of the party's chief goals of raising tax rates on high-income earners and corporations,” adding that this “increasingly appears like a red line” for the senator. The
Wall Street Journal
separately
reported
that Sinema “has told lobbyists that she is opposed to any increase in those rates.”
Neither story mentioned Sinema
voted no
on the Trump tax cuts as a House lawmaker and also opposed them during her 2018 campaign for Senate.
“A broken Congress failed again to deliver for hardworking Arizonans,” Sinema
said

of the tax law when it passed in late 2017. “Arizonans want fiscally responsible tax reform that gives families a chance to get ahead.” She added: “I’m ready to fix the problems and mistakes that will inevitably become clear as we learn more about the harmful consequences of this rushed and partisan tax bill.”

children.html: Tip Jar

children.text: Sinema
did
vote
to make the Trump law’s individual tax cuts permanent in September 2018.
But a few weeks later, during the final days of her Senate campaign, Sinema
ran
a digital ad
criticizing the Trump tax law, attacking Trump and her Republican opponent Martha McSally for supporting "huge tax breaks for the wealthy and large corporations at the expense of our middle class.”

TODAY’S CLICKS:
DOD OFFICIAL DEPARTS TO LEAD BOEING’S WEAPON SALES:
Heidi Grant, the Department of Defense official
responsible for overseeing U.S. foreign arms sales
, will leave her post to join Boeing next month as their new vice president of business development. Grant, who currently serves as the director of the U.S. Defense Security Cooperation Agency, will
head up defense, space, and government services sales
at the company, which enjoyed a
975 percent return
on its stock during the Afghanistan War.
BATES COLLEGE EMPLOYS ANTI-UNION PRESSURE CAMPAIGN:
Last Wednesday, the administration of Bates College in Maine
pressured the campus newspaper

to take down an article about employees’ plans to unionize adjunct faculty and non-managerial staff in an effort to increase pay and improve working conditions. The next day, the newspaper published a revised version of the story, complete with anti-union sentiment and a
pull quote from college President Clayton Spencer
that read: “No one can make an informed choice if they hear only one side of a story.”
AMERICA’S RICHEST HAVE GOTTEN RICHER DURING COVID:
A new Americans For Tax Fairness
report

shows America’s billionaires are 70 percent richer now than when the COVID-19 pandemic began. As of this month, the nation’s 745 billionaires are worth $5 trillion, $2 trillion more than the group was worth last March. The report noted, “On average, billionaires pay an effective federal income tax rate of about 8% when the increased value of their stock is counted, according to the White House. This is a lower rate than many middle-income taxpayers pay like teachers, nurses and firefighters.”

children.html: Give a Gift Subscription

children.text: CIVIL LIBERTIES GROUPS DEMAND BIDEN DROPS ASSANGE CASE:
Leading civil liberties organizations have re-upped their demand that Attorney General Merrick Garland abandons the Justice Departments’ criminal prosecution of Julian Assange in light of Yahoo News’
bombshell
last month detailing a CIA plot to kidnap and potentially assassinate the WikiLeaks founder. The
new letter
, signed by 24 organizations including the ACLU and Amnesty International USA, builds upon
previous requests
to drop the Assange case “on the grounds that his prosecution for publishing classified documents would be a threat to First Amendment press freedoms.”
KAINE CALLS RAHM EMANUEL’S POLICE MURDER COVER-UP “SCAR TISSUE”:

During Rahm Emanuel’s confirmation hearing for the Japan ambassadorship yesterday, on the seventh anniversary of the Chicago police murder of teenager Laquan McDonald, Emanuel parroted hawkish talking points on China while senators assisted him in explaining away
his cover-up of McDonald’s murder

. “You can’t be a mayor, especially in a city like Chicago, without picking up some scar tissue on the way,” said Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia about the cover-up. Meanwhile, Emanuel did not face any questions about his
lucrative consulting work
for fossil fuel and pharmaceutical clients over the past two years.
